Trial_Design.evidence: We conducted a pilot prospective randomized controlled trial

Participants.evidence: reverse obliquity fractures of the proximal femur from January 2009 to December 2009. There were 15 patients with standard nails and 18 with long nails.

Intervention.evidence: comparing standard versus long (≥ 34 cm) intramedullary hip nails

Objective.evidence: We compared standard and long types of intramedullary hip nails in terms of (1) reoperation (fixation failure), (2) 1-year mortality rate, (3) function and mobility, and (4) union rate.

Method_Outcome.evidence: We determined 1-year mortality rates, reoperation rates, Parker-Palmer mobility and Harris hip scores, and radiographic findings

Number_Randomised.evidence: There were 15 patients with standard nails and 18 with long nails.

Number_Analysed.evidence: We found no difference in reoperation rates between groups.

Result_Outcome.evidence: There was no difference between the standard- and long-nail groups in mortality rate (17% versus 18%), Parker-Palmer mobility score (five versus six), Harris hip score (74 versus 79), union rate (100% in both groups), blade cut-out (zero versus one), and tip-apex distance (22 versus 24 mm).

Harms.evidence: Two patients (both from the long-nail group) underwent revision surgery because of implant failure in one and deep infection in the other.
